user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2BinFile:
```c
bool UtMem2BinFile(const void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE *fp;

    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "w")))
    {
        fwrite(Memory, Length, 1, fp);
        fclose(fp);
        return true;
    }
    else
    {
        printf("UtMem2BinFile: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2BinFile: Error Opening File");
        return false;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtMem2BinFile:
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
fwrite(Memory, Length, 1, fp);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17: the code calls fwrite (stdio.h), not any of the string.h functions listed in Rule 21.17. Note: there remains a separate possible runtime safety concern if the object pointed to by Memory is smaller than Length (this would be a buffer over-read), but that is not covered by Rule 21.17.
